subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Last night I
had a dream and in this dream it was as
if I was inside the image that I have
posted as the header for the New
Thinking Allowed Psi Experience Community
group on Facebook. I'm showing you that
image right now. And as if I was there
walking out on that platform, facing this
void of clouds and then I jumped. I leapt
into the cloudy void in my dream. In
the dream I had the feeling that this is
it, I'm dying. There was no sadness or
discomfort. It was just a realization
like, okay here we go.
It has caused me to think a little
bit about - of course the meaning of the
dream as naturally any dream can be
interpreted on multiple levels - but this
dream of course suggests that I am taking a
dive. I am diving into a new arena for me,
places that I haven't yet been, the
cloudy void. It sort of reminds me of the
mystical cloud of unknowing. But, it
suggests a number of other things about
death and dying as well. I suppose it
also... here I am in my seventies, I’m at a
phase in life when lots of people begin
to think about their death. You know when
you’re young, when I was young, at least I
can say that, death seemed like far, far
away. I don’t even have to consider it. It’s
so far into the future. But now, I realize,
you know, I might have, well, on the
outside, maybe 40, 50 years left. I think
it's fair to say that by every
demographic statistics, my life
is more than 50% over. Now
frankly, I'd be okay living to be, let's
say 120. That might
even be a new record, although by the
time I get there I doubt if it will be
because life spans are increasing. But the
point I want to make here is this. In the
Bible, in the book of Deuteronomy, it says,
“I've given you a choice. I have set before
you a choice. You can choose life or you
can choose death. And I urge you to
choose life. Life means obedience to God.
Death means destruction. Choose life, not
death, because with life you will inherit
the land that you were about to enter as
the Jewish people were about to enter
the Holy land.” However, there's a
different ethos in Buddhism, where Buddha
says, “As you enter into a state of
Nirvana, you lose your attachment to life.
It doesn't matter, alive or dead, either
is fine.” Why would the Buddha say that?
Of course, one reason is because the
Buddha talked about past lives. The
Buddha has the Jataka Tales,
tales of the past lives of the Buddha,
both his human and non-human. But you see,
he didn't seem to care about losing his
life, clinging to life, grasping to life,
because he knew something is going to
continue anyway and that something is a
very elusive something. You know, there
was a story that is told that the Buddha
is telling his tales of his past lives
and afterwards one of the disciples
comes up to him and says, “So, I see. Master,
you believe in reincarnation.” The
Buddha said, “No.” The
disciple said, “Well, I guess then
you don't believe in reincarnation.” The
Buddha said, “No.” Afterwards the
Buddha’s scribe, his cousin Ananda said
to him, “Why did you do that? Why did
you say, no, you don't believe in
reincarnation, and no, you don't not
believe in reincarnation?” And the Buddha
said, “Well, either way he would have
misunderstood me.
The concept is subtle. It’s complex and
can easily be misunderstood.” The
Buddha also told people, “Don't show off
your psychic abilities, because if you do,
people are going to assume that it's
because you're wearing a particular
amulet that you have these abilities and
you don't want to confuse them. That's
not what it's about.” Now, I think in my
case, there's pretty good reason to
accept the data of reincarnation. At
least some people reincarnate of the
2,500 cases or so in the database at the
University of Virginia. I understand from
my interviews with Jim Matlock maybe
1,300 of them have been
solved. So, you might say we have evidence
now that 1,300 people have
reincarnated. What does that mean to me?
What does it mean to you? Are we going to
reincarnate because some people do? Who
knows? I would say there's a good chance
that not everybody does reincarnate. At
least not right away, according to Manly
Palmer Hall, the esoteric
metaphysical writer, the period in-
between lives is typically 2,500 years.
Well, that's a lot longer than the
periods that we find in the research
database, so it may well be that that
research database is skewed for all
sorts of reasons. So in my case, my
willingness to leap into the cloudy void
in my dream, my willingness to just, I guess
you’d have to say, embrace death - if it's
going to come, it's going to come. Well, the
truth is, it’s going to come. Physical
bodies
only last so long. Although I do know
people who believe in the immortality of
the physical body. Yes, there are people
who are striving for that and God bless
them. I wish them well. But it's probably
going to be an uphill battle. Although I
do recall, over ten years ago, a British
scientist said the first person to live
to be a thousand has just turned sixty. And
at that point, I had just turned sixty, so I
was intrigued. He was talking about
genetic engineering and the idea that we
can put viruses into our body, the
influenza virus will penetrate every
cell of your body and if you can program
that virus to cure certain ailments and
illnesses, it may be a miraculous
technique that will allow people to
recover from health conditions that are
currently deadly. And I think he
was going in that direction. But my own
sense is this. First of all, it's
inevitable. We're all going to experience
the death of our physical bodies, so why
not embrace it? Why should we be afraid
of death? I think that the culture
that we have around death and dying and
the fear of it is probably not the
healthiest thing in the world. There's
good evidence in parapsychology and it
suggests, and that's what I'm going to say,
suggests that there's a lot more waiting
for us out there.
In fact, there's good evidence, it was
just published in the Scientific
American website, a wonderful editorial
suggesting that consciousness is primary
and that the careful study of quantum
theory
shows us this, that if we really want to
gather the true meaning of quantum
theory, it’s that everything exists in
consciousness. That's because of the
notion that the collapse of the wave
function in quantum theory only occurs
when an observation is made, so the
conscious observer becomes part of the
process, a necessary part of the process.
Otherwise, everything is just a vague
probability cloud. Nothing happens until
somebody observes it, until there is a
sentient being observing everything. Well,
that's one of the main interpretations
of quantum physics. I can say it's not
the only one. There are other
interpretations. But the main message I
want to leave you with is the idea of
taking that leap. I'm reminded of the
movie, Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,
where he's in a cave-like temple as I
recall, Temple of the Sun. It’s a
dark cave and he's being chased and he
comes to a place where he has to leap. It
looks like he's going to leap into the
void and maybe fall into a chasm and
kill himself,
but he takes the step and he discovers
there is an invisible bridge that holds
him up and he can walk across it.
Many people interpreted that movie to
mean that you do have to take a leap of
faith. There are times in
your life where you have to count on the
Universe, somehow, being there to support
you. Now, that's an optimistic view. I
know not all the views of the world are
optimistic. George Orwell in 1984 painted
a very pessimistic view of our society
and of our politics. My good friend
Jason Reza Jorjani in his review of
the novel The Blind Owl, the novelette
by the great Persian writer Sadegh Hedayat,
paints a very dark picture of what
he calls the super sensible world.
When we begin exploring our psychic
capacities, what are we opening ourselves
up to? Some people are afraid it's the
devil. As far as I'm concerned, we're
opening ourselves up to the Universe.
We are the Universe. We're opening
ourselves up to our own depth. Should we
be afraid of ourselves? Should we be
afraid of ourselves? That's really the
question. I'll leave you with that
question to ponder. Thank you for being
with me.
